Foreign residents of Berlin originate from about 190 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-107"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-107">[105]</a></sup> 48 percent of the residents under the age of 15 have migration background.<sup id="cite_ref-108"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-108">[106]</a></sup> Berlin in 2009 was estimated to have 100,000 to 250,000 unregistered inhabitants.<sup id="cite_ref-109"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-109">[107]</a></sup> Boroughs of Berlin with a significant number of migrants or foreign born population are [Mitte](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mitte "Mitte"), [Neukölln](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neuk%C3%B6lln "Neukölln") and [Friedrichshain-Kreuzberg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friedrichshain-Kreuzberg "Friedrichshain-Kreuzberg").<sup id="cite_ref-110"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-110">[108]</a></sup>

There are more than 20 non-indigenous communities with a population of at least 10,000 people, including [Turkish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turks_in_Berlin "Turks in Berlin"), Polish, Russian, Lebanese, Palestinian, Serbian, Italian, Indian, Bosnian, [Vietnamese](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vietnamese_community_of_Berlin "Vietnamese community of Berlin"), American, Romanian, Bulgarian, Croatian, Chinese, Austrian, Ukrainian, French, British, Spanish, Israeli, Thai, Iranian, Egyptian and Syrian communities.<sup>[<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (April 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>

### Languages\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Languages")\]

German is the official and predominant spoken language in Berlin. It is a [West Germanic language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Germanic_languages "West Germanic languages") that derives most of its vocabulary from the Germanic branch of the [Indo-European](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indo-European_languages "Indo-European languages") language family. German is one of 24 languages of the European Union,<sup id="cite_ref-111"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-111">[109]</a></sup> and one of the three [working languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Working_language "Working language") of the [European Commission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Commission "European Commission").

Berlinerisch or Berlinisch is not a dialect linguistically. It is spoken in Berlin and the [surrounding metropolitan area](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin/Brandenburg_Metropolitan_Region "Berlin/Brandenburg Metropolitan Region"). It originates from a [Brandenburgish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brandenburgisch_dialect "Brandenburgisch dialect") variant. The dialect is now seen more like a [sociolect](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sociolect "Sociolect"), largely through increased immigration and trends among the educated population to speak [standard German](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standard_German "Standard German") in everyday life.

The most commonly spoken foreign languages in Berlin are Turkish, Polish, English, Persian, Arabic, Italian, Bulgarian, Russian, Romanian, Kurdish, Serbo-Croatian, French, Spanish and Vietnamese. Turkish, Arabic, Kurdish, and Serbo-Croatian are heard more often in the western part due to the large Middle Eastern and former-Yugoslavian communities. Polish, English, Russian, and Vietnamese have more native speakers in East Berlin.<sup id="cite_ref-112"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-112">[110]</a></sup>

### Religion\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Religion")\]

On the report of the 2011 census, approximately 37 percent of the population reported being members of a legally-recognized church or religious organization. The rest either did not belong to such an organization, or there was no information available about them.<sup id="cite_ref-Census_2011_113-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-Census_2011-113">[111]</a></sup>

The largest religious denomination recorded in 2010 was the [Protestant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protestant "Protestant") [regional church body](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Landeskirche "Landeskirche")—the [Evangelical Church of Berlin-Brandenburg-Silesian Upper Lusatia (EKBO)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evangelical_Church_of_Berlin-Brandenburg-Silesian_Upper_Lusatia "Evangelical Church of Berlin-Brandenburg-Silesian Upper Lusatia")—a [united church](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_church "United church"). EKBO is a member of the [Evangelical Church in Germany (EKD)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evangelical_Church_in_Germany "Evangelical Church in Germany") and [Union Evangelischer Kirchen (UEK)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Union_Evangelischer_Kirchen "Union Evangelischer Kirchen"). According to the EKBO, their membership accounted for 18.7 percent of the local population, while the [Roman Catholic Church](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catholic_Church "Catholic Church") had 9.1 percent of residents registered as its members.<sup id="cite_ref-kirchenmitglieder2010_114-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-kirchenmitglieder2010-114">[112]</a></sup> About 2.7% of the population identify with other Christian denominations (mostly [Eastern Orthodox](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church "Eastern Orthodox Church"), but also various Protestants).<sup id="cite_ref-klStatistik2010_115-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-klStatistik2010-115">[113]</a></sup> According to the Berlin residents register, in 2018 14.9 percent were members of the Evangelical Church, and 8.5 percent were members of the Catholic Church.<sup id="cite_ref-pop-detail-2019_99-4"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-pop-detail-2019-99">[97]</a></sup> The government keeps a register of members of these churches for tax purposes, because it collects [church tax](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Church_tax#Germany "Church tax") on behalf of the churches. It does not keep records of members of other religious organizations which may collect their own church tax, in this way.

In 2009, approximately 249,000 [Muslims](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muslim "Muslim") were reported by the [Office of Statistics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amt_f%C3%BCr_Statistik_Berlin-Brandenburg "Amt für Statistik Berlin-Brandenburg") to be members of mosques and Islamic religious organizations in Berlin,<sup id="cite_ref-116"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-116">[114]</a></sup> while in 2016, the newspaper _[Der Tagesspiegel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Der_Tagesspiegel "Der Tagesspiegel")_ estimated that about 350,000 Muslims observed [Ramadan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ramadan "Ramadan") in Berlin.<sup id="cite_ref-117"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-117">[115]</a></sup> In 2019, about 437,000 registered residents, 11.6% of the total, reported having a migration background from one of the [Member states of the Organization of Islamic Cooperation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Member_states_of_the_Organization_of_Islamic_Cooperation "Member states of the Organization of Islamic Cooperation").<sup id="cite_ref-pop-detail-2019_99-5"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-pop-detail-2019-99">[97]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-118"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-118">[116]</a></sup> Between 1992 and 2011 the Muslim population almost doubled.<sup id="cite_ref-119"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-119">[117]</a></sup>

About 0.9% of Berliners belong to other religions. Of the estimated population of 30,000–45,000 Jewish residents,<sup id="cite_ref-The_Boston_Globe_2014-11-01_120-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-The_Boston_Globe_2014-11-01-120">[118]</a></sup> approximately 12,000 are registered members of religious organizations.<sup id="cite_ref-klStatistik2010_115-1"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-klStatistik2010-115">[113]</a></sup>

Berlin is the seat of the [Roman Catholic archbishop of Berlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Archdiocese_of_Berlin "Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Berlin") and [EKBO](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evangelical_Church_of_Berlin-Brandenburg-Silesian_Upper_Lusatia "Evangelical Church of Berlin-Brandenburg-Silesian Upper Lusatia")'s elected chairperson is titled the bishop of EKBO. Furthermore, Berlin is the seat of many Orthodox cathedrals, such as the Cathedral of St. Boris the Baptist, one of the two seats of the [Bulgarian Orthodox](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bulgarian_Orthodox_Church "Bulgarian Orthodox Church") Diocese of Western and Central Europe, and the Resurrection of Christ Cathedral of the Diocese of Berlin (Patriarchate of Moscow).

The faithful of the different religions and denominations maintain many [places of worship in Berlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_places_of_worship_in_Berlin "List of places of worship in Berlin"). The [Independent Evangelical Lutheran Church](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Independent_Evangelical_Lutheran_Church "Independent Evangelical Lutheran Church") has eight parishes of different sizes in Berlin.<sup id="cite_ref-121"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-121">[119]</a></sup> There are 36 [Baptist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baptist "Baptist") congregations (within [Union of Evangelical Free Church Congregations in Germany](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Union_of_Evangelical_Free_Church_Congregations_in_Germany "Union of Evangelical Free Church Congregations in Germany")), 29 [New Apostolic Churches](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Apostolic_Church "New Apostolic Church"), 15 [United Methodist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Methodist "United Methodist") churches, eight Free Evangelical Congregations, four [Churches of Christ, Scientist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Church_of_Christ,_Scientist "Church of Christ, Scientist") (1st, 2nd, 3rd, and 11th), six congregations of [the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Church_of_Jesus_Christ_of_Latter-day_Saints "The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints"), an [Old Catholic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_Catholic "Old Catholic") church, and an [Anglican](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anglican "Anglican") church in Berlin. Berlin has more than 80 mosques,<sup id="cite_ref-122"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-122">[120]</a></sup> ten synagogues,<sup id="cite_ref-123"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-123">[121]</a></sup> and two [Buddhist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buddhist "Buddhist") temples.

## Government and politics\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Government and politics")\]

### City state\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: City state")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Rotes_Rathaus.jpg/220px-Rotes_Rathaus.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Rotes_Rathaus.jpg)

[Rotes Rathaus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rotes_Rathaus "Rotes Rathaus") (_Red City Hall_), seat of the Senate and Mayor of Berlin

Since [reunification](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/German_reunification "German reunification") on 3 October 1990, Berlin has been one of the three [city states in Germany](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/States_of_Germany#Subdivisions "States of Germany") among the present 16 states of Germany. The [House of Representatives](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abgeordnetenhaus_von_Berlin "Abgeordnetenhaus von Berlin") (_Abgeordnetenhaus_) functions as the city and state parliament, which has 141 seats. Berlin's executive body is the [Senate of Berlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Senate_of_Berlin "Senate of Berlin") (_Senat von Berlin_). The Senate consists of the [Governing Mayor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_mayors_of_Berlin "List of mayors of Berlin") (_Regierender Bürgermeister_), and up to ten senators holding ministerial positions, two of them holding the title of "Mayor" (_Bürgermeister_) as deputy to the Governing Mayor.<sup id="cite_ref-124"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-124">[122]</a></sup> The total annual state budget of Berlin in 2015 exceeded €24.5 ($30.0) billion including a budget surplus of €205 ($240) million.<sup id="cite_ref-125"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-125">[123]</a></sup> The state owns extensive assets, including administrative and government buildings, real estate companies, as well as stakes in the Olympic Stadium, swimming pools, housing companies, and numerous public enterprises and subsidiary companies.<sup id="cite_ref-126"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-126">[124]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-127"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-127">[125]</a></sup>

The [Social Democratic Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_of_Germany "Social Democratic Party of Germany") (SPD) and [The Left](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Left_(Germany) "The Left (Germany)") (Die Linke) took control of the city government after the [2001 state election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_state_election,_2001 "Berlin state election, 2001") and won another term in the [2006 state election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_state_election,_2006 "Berlin state election, 2006").<sup id="cite_ref-128"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-128">[126]</a></sup> Since the [2016 state election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_state_election,_2016 "Berlin state election, 2016"), there has been a coalition between the Social Democratic Party, the Greens and the Left Party.

The Governing Mayor is simultaneously Lord Mayor of the City of Berlin (_Oberbürgermeister der Stadt_) and Minister President of the State of Berlin (_Ministerpräsident des Bundeslandes_). The office of the Governing Mayor is in the [Rotes Rathaus (Red City Hall)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rotes_Rathaus "Rotes Rathaus"). Since 2021, this office has been held by [Franziska Giffey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franziska_Giffey "Franziska Giffey") of the Social Democrats.<sup id="cite_ref-129"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-129">[127]</a></sup>

### Boroughs\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Boroughs")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Berlin_Subdivisions.svg/290px-Berlin_Subdivisions.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Berlin_Subdivisions.svg)

Berlin is subdivided into 12 boroughs or districts (_Bezirke_). Each borough has several subdistricts or neighborhoods (_Ortsteile_), which have roots in much older municipalities that predate the formation of Greater Berlin on 1 October 1920. These subdistricts became urbanized and incorporated into the city later on. Many residents strongly identify with their neighborhoods, colloquially called _[Kiez](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kiez "Kiez")_. At present, Berlin consists of 96 subdistricts, which are commonly made up of several smaller residential areas or quarters.

Each borough is governed by a borough council (_Bezirksamt_) consisting of five councilors (_Bezirksstadträte_) including the borough's mayor (_Bezirksbürgermeister_). The council is elected by the borough assembly (_Bezirksverordnetenversammlung_). However, the individual boroughs are not independent municipalities, but subordinate to the Senate of Berlin. The borough's mayors make up the council of mayors (_Rat der Bürgermeister_), which is led by the city's Governing Mayor and advises the Senate. The neighborhoods have no local government bodies.

### Twin towns – sister cities\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Twin towns – sister cities")\]

Berlin maintains official partnerships with 17 cities.<sup id="cite_ref-Berlintwins_130-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-Berlintwins-130">[128]</a></sup> [Town twinning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sister_city "Sister city") between Berlin and other cities began with its sister city Los Angeles in 1967. East Berlin's partnerships were canceled at the time of German reunification but later partially reestablished. West Berlin's partnerships had previously been restricted to the borough level. During the Cold War era, the partnerships had reflected the different power blocs, with West Berlin partnering with capitals in the Western World and East Berlin mostly partnering with cities from the [Warsaw Pact](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warsaw_Pact "Warsaw Pact") and its allies.

There are several joint projects with many other cities, such as [Beirut](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beirut "Beirut"), Belgrade, São Paulo, [Copenhagen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Copenhagen "Copenhagen"), [Helsinki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helsinki "Helsinki"), [Amsterdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam "Amsterdam"), [Johannesburg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johannesburg "Johannesburg"), [Mumbai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mumbai "Mumbai"), Oslo, [Hanoi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hanoi "Hanoi"), Shanghai, [Seoul](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seoul "Seoul"), [Sofia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sofia "Sofia"), [Sydney](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sydney "Sydney"), New York City and [Vienna](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vienna "Vienna"). Berlin participates in international city associations such as the Union of the Capitals of the European Union, Eurocities, Network of European Cities of Culture, Metropolis, Summit Conference of the World's Major Cities, and Conference of the World's Capital Cities.

Berlin is twinned with:<sup id="cite_ref-Berlintwins_130-1"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-Berlintwins-130">[128]</a></sup>

-   Los Angeles, United States (1967)
-   [Madrid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madrid "Madrid"), Spain (1988)
-   [Istanbul](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Istanbul "Istanbul"), Turkey (1989)
-   [Warsaw](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warsaw "Warsaw"), Poland (1991)
-   Moscow, Russia (1991)
-   [Brussels](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brussels "Brussels"), Belgium (1992)
-   [Budapest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Budapest "Budapest"), Hungary (1992)
-   [Tashkent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tashkent "Tashkent"), Uzbekistan (1993)
-   [Mexico City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mexico_City "Mexico City"), Mexico (1993)
-   [Jakarta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jakarta "Jakarta"), Indonesia (1993)
-   Beijing, China (1994)
-   Tokyo, Japan (1994)
-   [Buenos Aires](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buenos_Aires "Buenos Aires"), Argentina (1994)
-   [Prague](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prague "Prague"), Czech Republic (1995)
-   [Windhoek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windhoek "Windhoek"), Namibia (2000)
-   London, United Kingdom (2000)

Since 1987, Berlin also has an official partnership with Paris, France. Every Berlin borough also established its own twin towns. For example, the borough of [Friedrichshain-Kreuzberg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friedrichshain-Kreuzberg "Friedrichshain-Kreuzberg") has a partnership with the Israeli city of [Kiryat Yam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kiryat_Yam "Kiryat Yam").<sup id="cite_ref-131"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-131">[129]</a></sup>

### Capital city\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: Capital city")\]

Berlin is the capital of the Federal Republic of Germany. The [President of Germany](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_Germany "President of Germany"), whose functions are mainly ceremonial under the [German constitution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grundgesetz "Grundgesetz"), has their official residence in [Bellevue Palace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bellevue_Palace_(Germany) "Bellevue Palace (Germany)").<sup id="cite_ref-132"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-132">[130]</a></sup> Berlin is the [seat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seat_of_government "Seat of government") of the [German Chancellor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chancellor_of_Germany_(1949%E2%80%93) "Chancellor of Germany (1949–)") (Prime Minister), housed in the [Chancellery building](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Chancellery_(Berlin) "Federal Chancellery (Berlin)"), the _Bundeskanzleramt_. Facing the Chancellery is the [Bundestag](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bundestag "Bundestag"), the German Parliament, housed in the renovated [Reichstag building](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reichstag_building "Reichstag building") since the government's relocation to Berlin in 1998. The [Bundesrat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bundesrat_of_Germany "Bundesrat of Germany") ("federal council", performing the function of an [upper house](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Upper_house "Upper house")) is the [representation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federalism "Federalism") of the [16 constituent states](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/States_of_Germany "States of Germany") (_Länder_) of Germany and has its seat at the former [Prussian House of Lords](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prussian_House_of_Lords "Prussian House of Lords"). The total annual federal budget managed by the German government exceeded €310 ($375) billion in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-133"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-133">[131]</a></sup>

-   [![The Federal Chancellery building, seat of the Chancellor of Germany](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/07.08.21.Bundeskanzleramt.jpg/523px-07.08.21.Bundeskanzleramt.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:07.08.21.Bundeskanzleramt.jpg "The Federal Chancellery building, seat of the Chancellor of Germany")
    

-   [![Schloss Bellevue, seat of the President of Germany](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Bellevue_Palace_Berlin_02-14.jpg/360px-Bellevue_Palace_Berlin_02-14.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Bellevue_Palace_Berlin_02-14.jpg "Schloss Bellevue, seat of the President of Germany")
    
-   [![Prussian House of Lords, seat of the Bundesrat of Germany](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Bundesrat_Geb%C3%A4ude%2C_Berlin%2C_Leipziger_Strasse.jpg/237px-Bundesrat_Geb%C3%A4ude%2C_Berlin%2C_Leipziger_Strasse.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Bundesrat_Geb%C3%A4ude,_Berlin,_Leipziger_Strasse.jpg "Prussian House of Lords, seat of the Bundesrat of Germany")
    
-   [![Headquarters of the Federal Intelligence Service](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Zentrale_des_Bundesnachrichtendienst%2C_Berlin.jpg/339px-Zentrale_des_Bundesnachrichtendienst%2C_Berlin.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Zentrale_des_Bundesnachrichtendienst,_Berlin.jpg "Headquarters of the Federal Intelligence Service")
    

The relocation of the federal [government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cabinet_of_Germany "Cabinet of Germany") and Bundestag to Berlin was mostly completed in 1999. However, some ministries, as well as some minor departments, stayed in the [federal city](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_city "Federal city") [Bonn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bonn "Bonn"), the former capital of West Germany. [Discussions about moving](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin-Bonn_Act "Berlin-Bonn Act") the remaining ministries and departments to Berlin continue.<sup id="cite_ref-134"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-134">[132]</a></sup> The [Federal Foreign Office](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foreign_Office_(Germany) "Foreign Office (Germany)") and the ministries and departments of [Defense](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Ministry_of_Defence_(Germany) "Federal Ministry of Defence (Germany)"), [Justice and Consumer Protection](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Ministry_of_Justice_and_Consumer_Protection "Federal Ministry of Justice and Consumer Protection"), [Finance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Ministry_of_Finance_(Germany) "Federal Ministry of Finance (Germany)"), [Interior](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Ministry_of_the_Interior_(Germany) "Federal Ministry of the Interior (Germany)"), [Economic Affairs and Energy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Ministry_for_Economic_Affairs_and_Energy_(Germany) "Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Energy (Germany)"), [Labor and Social Affairs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Ministry_of_Labour_and_Social_Affairs "Federal Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs"), [Family Affairs, Senior Citizens, Women and Youth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Ministry_of_Family_Affairs,_Senior_Citizens,_Women_and_Youth "Federal Ministry of Family Affairs, Senior Citizens, Women and Youth"), [Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Ministry_of_the_Environment,_Nature_Conservation_and_Nuclear_Safety "Federal Ministry of the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety"), [Food and Agriculture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Ministry_of_Food_and_Agriculture "Federal Ministry of Food and Agriculture"), [Economic Cooperation and Development](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Ministry_for_Economic_Cooperation_and_Development "Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development"), [Health](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Ministry_of_Health_(Germany) "Federal Ministry of Health (Germany)"), [Transport and Digital Infrastructure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Ministry_of_Transport_and_Digital_Infrastructure "Federal Ministry of Transport and Digital Infrastructure") and [Education and Research](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Ministry_of_Education_and_Research_(Germany) "Federal Ministry of Education and Research (Germany)") are based in the capital.

Berlin hosts in total 158 foreign embassies<sup id="cite_ref-135"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-135">[133]</a></sup> as well as the headquarters of many think tanks, trade unions, nonprofit organizations, lobbying groups, and professional associations. Due to the influence and international partnerships of the Federal Republic of Germany, the capital city has become a significant center of German and European affairs. Frequent official visits and diplomatic consultations among governmental representatives and national leaders are common in contemporary Berlin.

## Economy\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: Economy")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Berlin_Mitte_by_night.JPG/220px-Berlin_Mitte_by_night.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Berlin_Mitte_by_night.JPG)

In 2018, the GDP of Berlin totaled €147 billion, an increase of 3.1% over the previous year.<sup id="cite_ref-statoffice_1-3"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-statoffice-1">[1]</a></sup> Berlin's economy is dominated by the [service sector](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Service_sector "Service sector"), with around 84% of all companies doing business in services. In 2015, the total labor force in Berlin was 1.85 million. The unemployment rate reached a 24-year low in November 2015 and stood at 10.0%.<sup id="cite_ref-137"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-137">[135]</a></sup> From 2012 to 2015 Berlin, as a German state, had the highest annual employment growth rate. Around 130,000 jobs were added in this period.<sup id="cite_ref-138"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-138">[136]</a></sup>

Important economic sectors in Berlin include life sciences, transportation, information and communication technologies, media and music, advertising and design, biotechnology, environmental services, construction, e-commerce, retail, hotel business, and medical engineering.<sup id="cite_ref-139"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-139">[137]</a></sup>

Research and development have economic significance for the city.<sup id="cite_ref-factsheet_140-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-factsheet-140">[138]</a></sup> Several major corporations like Volkswagen, Pfizer, and SAP operate innovation laboratories in the city.<sup id="cite_ref-141"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-141">[139]</a></sup> The Science and Business Park in Adlershof is the largest technology park in Germany measured by revenue.<sup id="cite_ref-142"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-142">[140]</a></sup> Within the [Eurozone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eurozone "Eurozone"), Berlin has become a center for business relocation and international [investments](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Investment_(macroeconomics) "Investment (macroeconomics)").<sup id="cite_ref-143"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-143">[141]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-144"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-144">[142]</a></sup>

| Year<sup id="cite_ref-145"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-145">[143]</a></sup> | 2000 | 2001 | 2002 | 2003 | 2004 | 2005 | 2006 | 2007 | 2008 | 2009 | 2010 | 2011 | 2012 | 2013 | 2014 | 2015 | 2016 | 2017 | 2018 | 2019 |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Unemployment rate in % | 15.8 | 16.1 | 16.9 | 18.1 | 17.7 | 19.0 | 17.5 | 15.5 | 13.8 | 14.0 | 13.6 | 13.3 | 12.3 | 11.7 | 11.1 | 10.7 | 9.8 | 9.0 | 8.1 | 7.8 |

### Companies\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: Companies")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/DBBuildingBerling150809.jpg/170px-DBBuildingBerling150809.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:DBBuildingBerling150809.jpg)

[Deutsche Bahn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deutsche_Bahn "Deutsche Bahn"), the world's second-largest transport company, is headquartered in Berlin.

Many German and international companies have business or service centers in the city. For several years Berlin has been recognized as a major center of [business founders](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Entrepreneurship "Entrepreneurship").<sup id="cite_ref-146"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-146">[144]</a></sup> In 2015, Berlin generated the most venture capital for young [startup companies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Startup_company "Startup company") in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-147"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-147">[145]</a></sup>

Among the 10 largest employers in Berlin are the City-State of Berlin, [Deutsche Bahn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deutsche_Bahn "Deutsche Bahn"), the hospital providers [Charité](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charit%C3%A9 "Charité") and [Vivantes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vivantes "Vivantes"), the Federal Government of Germany, the local public transport provider [BVG](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berliner_Verkehrsbetriebe "Berliner Verkehrsbetriebe"), [Siemens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siemens "Siemens") and [Deutsche Telekom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deutsche_Telekom "Deutsche Telekom").<sup id="cite_ref-148"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-148">[146]</a></sup>

Siemens, a [Global 500](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fortune_Global_500 "Fortune Global 500") and [DAX](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DAX "DAX")\-listed company is partly headquartered in Berlin. Other DAX-listed companies headquartered in Berlin are the property company [Deutsche Wohnen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deutsche_Wohnen "Deutsche Wohnen") and the online food delivery service [Delivery Hero](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delivery_Hero "Delivery Hero"). The national railway operator [Deutsche Bahn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deutsche_Bahn "Deutsche Bahn"),<sup id="cite_ref-149"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-149">[147]</a></sup> Europe's largest digital publisher<sup id="cite_ref-150"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-150">[148]</a></sup> [Axel Springer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Axel_Springer_SE "Axel Springer SE") as well as the [MDAX](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MDAX "MDAX")\-listed firms [Zalando](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zalando "Zalando") and [HelloFresh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HelloFresh "HelloFresh") and also have their main headquarters in the city. Among the largest international corporations who have their German or European headquarters in Berlin are [Bombardier Transportation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bombardier_Transportation "Bombardier Transportation"), [Securing Energy for Europe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Securing_Energy_for_Europe "Securing Energy for Europe"), [Coca-Cola](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coca-Cola "Coca-Cola"), [Pfizer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pfizer "Pfizer"), [Sony](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sony "Sony") and [TotalEnergies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TotalEnergies "TotalEnergies").

As of 2018, the three largest banks headquartered in the capital were [Deutsche Kreditbank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deutsche_Kreditbank "Deutsche Kreditbank"), [Landesbank Berlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Landesbank_Berlin "Landesbank Berlin") and [Berlin Hyp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_Hyp "Berlin Hyp").<sup id="cite_ref-151"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-151">[149]</a></sup>

[Mercedes-Benz Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_Group "Mercedes-Benz Group") manufactures cars, and [BMW builds motorcycles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BMW_Motorrad "BMW Motorrad") in Berlin. In 2022, American electric car manufacturer [Tesla](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tesla,_Inc. "Tesla, Inc.") opened its first European Gigafactory outside the city borders in [Grünheide (Mark)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gr%C3%BCnheide_(Mark) "Grünheide (Mark)"), Brandenburg. The Pharmaceuticals division of [Bayer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayer "Bayer")<sup id="cite_ref-152"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-152">[150]</a></sup> and [Berlin Chemie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_Chemie "Berlin Chemie") are major pharmaceutical companies in the city.

### Tourism and conventions\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: Tourism and conventions")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Berlin_Fashion_Week_2013.jpg/206px-Berlin_Fashion_Week_2013.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Berlin_Fashion_Week_2013.jpg)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/IFA_2012_IMG_7677.JPG/206px-IFA_2012_IMG_7677.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:IFA_2012_IMG_7677.JPG)

[IFA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internationale_Funkausstellung_Berlin "Internationale Funkausstellung Berlin") is one of Europe's leading trade show for consumer electronics.

Berlin had 788 hotels with 134,399 beds in 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-visitberlin_153-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-visitberlin-153">[151]</a></sup> The city recorded 28.7 million overnight hotel stays and 11.9 million hotel guests in 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-visitberlin_153-1"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-visitberlin-153">[151]</a></sup> Tourism figures have more than doubled within the last ten years and Berlin has become the third-most-visited city destination in Europe. Some of the most visited places in Berlin include: [Potsdamer Platz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Potsdamer_Platz "Potsdamer Platz"), [Brandenburger Tor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brandenburg_Gate "Brandenburg Gate"), [the Berlin wall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_Wall "Berlin Wall"), [Alexanderplatz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexanderplatz "Alexanderplatz"), [Museumsinsel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_Island "Museum Island"), [Fernsehturm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fernsehturm_Berlin "Fernsehturm Berlin"), the [East-Side Gallery](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Side_Gallery "East Side Gallery"), [Schloss-Charlottenburg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charlottenburg_Palace "Charlottenburg Palace"), [Zoologischer Garten](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_Zoological_Garden "Berlin Zoological Garden"), [Siegessäule](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_Victory_Column "Berlin Victory Column"), [Gedenkstätte Berliner Mauer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gedenkst%C3%A4tte_Berliner_Mauer "Gedenkstätte Berliner Mauer"), [Mauerpark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mauerpark "Mauerpark"), [Botanical Garden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin-Dahlem_Botanical_Garden_and_Botanical_Museum "Berlin-Dahlem Botanical Garden and Botanical Museum"), [Französischer Dom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_Cathedral,_Berlin "French Cathedral, Berlin"), [Deutscher Dom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deutscher_Dom "Deutscher Dom") and [Holocaust-Mahnmal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memorial_to_the_Murdered_Jews_of_Europe "Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe"). The largest visitor groups are from Germany, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, Italy, Spain and the United States.

According to figures from the [International Congress and Convention Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Congress_and_Convention_Association "International Congress and Convention Association") in 2015, Berlin became the leading organizer of conferences globally, hosting 195 international meetings.<sup id="cite_ref-154"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-154">[152]</a></sup> Some of these congress events take place on venues such as CityCube Berlin or the Berlin Congress Center (bcc).

The [Messe Berlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Messe_Berlin "Messe Berlin") (also known as Berlin ExpoCenter City) is the main convention organizing company in the city. Its main exhibition area covers more than 160,000 square meters (1,722,226 sq ft). Several large-scale trade fairs like the consumer electronics trade fair [IFA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IFA_Berlin "IFA Berlin"), the [ILA Berlin Air Show](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ILA_Berlin_Air_Show "ILA Berlin Air Show"), the [Berlin Fashion Week](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_Fashion_Week "Berlin Fashion Week") (including the _Premium Berlin_ and the _Panorama Berlin_),<sup id="cite_ref-155"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-155">[153]</a></sup> the [Green Week](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_International_Green_Week "Berlin International Green Week"), the _Fruit Logistica_, the transport fair [InnoTrans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/InnoTrans "InnoTrans"), the tourism fair [ITB](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ITB_Berlin "ITB Berlin") and the adult entertainment and erotic fair [Venus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venus_Award "Venus Award") are held annually in the city, attracting a significant number of business visitors.

### Creative industries\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: Creative industries")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/European_Film_Academy_-_European_Film_Awards_logo.svg/220px-European_Film_Academy_-_European_Film_Awards_logo.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:European_Film_Academy_-_European_Film_Awards_logo.svg)

The [creative arts and entertainment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Creative_industries "Creative industries") business is an important part of Berlin's economy. The sector comprises music, film, advertising, architecture, art, design, [fashion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/German_fashion "German fashion"), performing arts, publishing, [R&D](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Research_and_development "Research and development"), software,<sup id="cite_ref-156"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-156">[154]</a></sup> TV, radio, and [video games](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_gaming_in_Germany "Video gaming in Germany").

In 2014, around 30,500 creative companies operated in the Berlin-Brandenburg metropolitan region, predominantly [SMEs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Small_and_medium-sized_enterprises "Small and medium-sized enterprises"). Generating a revenue of 15.6 billion Euro and 6% of all private economic sales, the culture industry grew from 2009 to 2014 at an average rate of 5.5% per year.<sup id="cite_ref-157"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-157">[155]</a></sup>

Berlin is an important European and [German film industry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cinema_of_Germany "Cinema of Germany") hub.<sup id="cite_ref-158"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-158">[156]</a></sup> It is home to more than 1,000 film and television production companies, 270 movie theaters, and around 300 national and international co-productions are filmed in the region every year.<sup id="cite_ref-factsheet_140-1"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-factsheet-140">[138]</a></sup> The historic [Babelsberg Studios](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Babelsberg_Studios "Babelsberg Studios") and the production company [UFA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universum_Film_AG "Universum Film AG") are adjacent to Berlin in [Potsdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Potsdam "Potsdam"). The city is also home of the [German Film Academy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deutsche_Filmakademie "Deutsche Filmakademie") (Deutsche Filmakademie), founded in 2003, and the [European Film Academy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Film_Academy "European Film Academy"), founded in 1988.

### Media\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: Media")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Axel-Springer-Neubau_Berlin%2C_1._Juli_2019_01.jpg/220px-Axel-Springer-Neubau_Berlin%2C_1._Juli_2019_01.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Axel-Springer-Neubau_Berlin,_1._Juli_2019_01.jpg)

Berlin is home to many magazine, newspaper, book, and scientific/academic publishers and their associated service industries. In addition, around 20 news agencies, more than 90 regional daily newspapers and their websites, as well as the Berlin offices of more than 22 national publications such as [Der Spiegel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Der_Spiegel "Der Spiegel"), and [Die Zeit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Die_Zeit "Die Zeit") reinforce the capital's position as Germany's epicenter for influential debate. Therefore, many international journalists, bloggers, and writers live and work in the city.

Berlin is the central location to several international and regional television and radio stations.<sup id="cite_ref-159"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-159">[157]</a></sup> The public broadcaster [RBB](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rundfunk_Berlin-Brandenburg "Rundfunk Berlin-Brandenburg") has its headquarters in Berlin as well as the commercial broadcasters [MTV Europe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MTV_Europe "MTV Europe") and [Welt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Welt_(German_TV_channel) "Welt (German TV channel)"). German international public broadcaster [Deutsche Welle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deutsche_Welle "Deutsche Welle") has its TV production unit in Berlin, and most national German broadcasters have a studio in the city, including [ZDF](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ZDF "ZDF") and [RTL](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RTL_Television "RTL Television").

Berlin has Germany's largest number of daily newspapers, with numerous local [broadsheets](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Broadsheet "Broadsheet") (_[Berliner Morgenpost](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berliner_Morgenpost "Berliner Morgenpost")_, _[Berliner Zeitung](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berliner_Zeitung "Berliner Zeitung")_, _[Der Tagesspiegel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Der_Tagesspiegel "Der Tagesspiegel")_), and three major [tabloids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tabloid_(newspaper_format) "Tabloid (newspaper format)"), as well as national dailies of varying sizes, each with a different political affiliation, such as _[Die Welt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Die_Welt "Die Welt")_, _[Neues Deutschland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neues_Deutschland "Neues Deutschland")_, and _[Die Tageszeitung](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Die_Tageszeitung "Die Tageszeitung")_. The _[Exberliner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exberliner "Exberliner")_, a monthly magazine, is Berlin's English-language periodical and [La Gazette de Berlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/La_Gazette_de_Berlin "La Gazette de Berlin") a French-language newspaper.

Berlin is also the headquarter of major German-language publishing houses like [Walter de Gruyter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walter_de_Gruyter "Walter de Gruyter"), [Springer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Axel_Springer_AG "Axel Springer AG"), the Ullstein Verlagsgruppe (publishing group), [Suhrkamp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suhrkamp "Suhrkamp"), and Cornelsen are all based in Berlin. Each of which publishes books, periodicals, and multimedia products.

## Quality of life\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Quality of life")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Erster_Spreestrand.JPG/195px-Erster_Spreestrand.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Erster_Spreestrand.JPG)

Berlin is one of the world's most livable cities.

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Simon-Dach-Stra%C3%9Fe_Berlin.jpg/220px-Simon-Dach-Stra%C3%9Fe_Berlin.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Simon-Dach-Stra%C3%9Fe_Berlin.jpg)

Typical street scene at Simon-Dach-Straße

According to [Mercer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercer_(consulting_firm) "Mercer (consulting firm)"), Berlin ranked number 13 in the Quality of living city ranking in 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-160"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-160">[158]</a></sup>

According to [_Monocle_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monocle_(UK_magazine) "Monocle (UK magazine)"), Berlin occupies the position of the 6th-most-livable city in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-161"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-161">[159]</a></sup> [Economist Intelligence Unit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economist_Intelligence_Unit "Economist Intelligence Unit") ranks Berlin number 21 of all global cities.<sup id="cite_ref-162"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-162">[160]</a></sup> Berlin is number 8 at the [Global Power City Index](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Global_Power_City_Index&action=edit&redlink=1 "Global Power City Index (page does not exist)").<sup id="cite_ref-163"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-163">[161]</a></sup>

In 2019, Berlin has the best future prospects of all cities in Germany, according to HWWI and [Berenberg Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berenberg_Bank "Berenberg Bank").<sup id="cite_ref-164"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-164">[162]</a></sup> According to the 2019 study by Forschungsinstitut Prognos, Berlin was ranked number 92 of all 401 regions in Germany. It is also the 4th ranked region in former [East Germany](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Germany "East Germany") after [Jena](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jena "Jena"), [Dresden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dresden "Dresden") and [Potsdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Potsdam "Potsdam").<sup id="cite_ref-165"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-165">[163]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-166"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-166">[164]</a></sup>

## Infrastructure\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Infrastructure")\]

### Transport\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=28 "Edit section: Transport")\]

#### Roads\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: Roads")\]

Berlin's transport infrastructure is highly complex, providing a diverse range of urban mobility.<sup id="cite_ref-167"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-167">[165]</a></sup> A total of 979 bridges cross 197 km (122 mi) of inner-city waterways. 5,422 km (3,369 mi) of roads run through Berlin, of which 77 km (48 mi) are motorways (_[Autobahn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autobahn "Autobahn")_).<sup id="cite_ref-statistics_168-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-statistics-168">[166]</a></sup> In 2013, 1.344 million motor vehicles were registered in the city.<sup id="cite_ref-statistics_168-1"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-statistics-168">[166]</a></sup> With 377 cars per 1000 residents in 2013 (570/1000 in Germany), Berlin as a Western global city has one of the lowest numbers of cars per capita.<sup id="cite_ref-169"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-169">[167]</a></sup> In 2012, around 7,600 mostly beige colored [taxicabs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taxicab "Taxicab") were in service.<sup>[<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2021)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Since 2011, a number of app based [e-car](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electric_vehicle "Electric vehicle") and [e-scooter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electric_motorcycles_and_scooters "Electric motorcycles and scooters") sharing services have evolved.

#### Rail\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=30 "Edit section: Rail")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Berlin_Hauptbahnhof0514.JPG/220px-Berlin_Hauptbahnhof0514.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Berlin_Hauptbahnhof0514.JPG)

Long-distance rail lines connect Berlin with all of the major cities of Germany and with many cities in neighboring European countries. Regional rail lines of the _[Verkehrsverbund Berlin-Brandenburg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verkehrsverbund_Berlin-Brandenburg "Verkehrsverbund Berlin-Brandenburg")_ provide access to the surrounding regions of Brandenburg and to the [Baltic Sea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baltic_Sea "Baltic Sea"). The [Berlin Hauptbahnhof](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_Hauptbahnhof "Berlin Hauptbahnhof") is the largest [grade-separated](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grade_separation "Grade separation") railway station in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-170"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-170">[168]</a></sup> [Deutsche Bahn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deutsche_Bahn "Deutsche Bahn") runs high speed [Intercity-Express](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intercity-Express "Intercity-Express") trains to domestic destinations like [Hamburg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamburg "Hamburg"), [Munich](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Munich "Munich"), [Cologne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cologne "Cologne"), [Stuttgart](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stuttgart "Stuttgart"), [Frankfurt am Main](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frankfurt_am_Main "Frankfurt am Main") and others. It also runs an airport express rail service, as well as trains to several international destinations like [Vienna](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vienna "Vienna"), Prague, [Zürich](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Z%C3%BCrich "Zürich"), [Warsaw](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warsaw "Warsaw"), [Wrocław](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wroc%C5%82aw "Wrocław"), [Budapest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Budapest "Budapest") and [Amsterdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam "Amsterdam").

#### Water transport\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section: Water transport")\]

Berlin is connected to the [Elbe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elbe "Elbe") and [Oder](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oder "Oder") rivers via the [Spree](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spree_(river) "Spree (river)") and the [Havel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Havel "Havel") rivers. There are no frequent passenger connections to and from Berlin by water, but some of the freight is transported via waterways. Berlin's largest harbour, the [Westhafen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Westhafen "Westhafen"), is located in the district of [Moabit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moabit "Moabit"). It is a transhipment and storage site for inland shipping with a growing importance.<sup id="cite_ref-171"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-171">[169]</a></sup>

#### Intercity buses\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=32 "Edit section: Intercity buses")\]

Similarly to other German cities, there is an increasing quantity of [intercity bus services](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intercity_bus_service "Intercity bus service"). The city has more than 10 stations<sup id="cite_ref-172"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-172">[170]</a></sup> that run buses to destinations throughout Germany and Europe, Zentraler Omnibusbahnhof Berlin being the biggest station.

#### Public transport\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=33 "Edit section: Public transport")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Berlin_-_U-Bahnhof_Heidelberger_Platz_S%C3%BCdzugang.jpg/220px-Berlin_-_U-Bahnhof_Heidelberger_Platz_S%C3%BCdzugang.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Berlin_-_U-Bahnhof_Heidelberger_Platz_S%C3%BCdzugang.jpg)

The _[Berliner Verkehrsbetriebe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berliner_Verkehrsbetriebe "Berliner Verkehrsbetriebe")_ (BVG) and the Deutsche Bahn (DB) manage several extensive urban public transport systems.<sup id="cite_ref-173"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-173">[171]</a></sup>

| System | Stations / Lines / Net length | Annual ridership | Operator / Notes |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| [S-Bahn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_S-Bahn "Berlin S-Bahn") | 166 / 16 / 331 km (206 mi) | 431,000,000 (2016) | [DB](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deutsche_Bahn "Deutsche Bahn") / Mainly overground [rapid transit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rapid_transit "Rapid transit") rail system with suburban stops |
| [U-Bahn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_U-Bahn "Berlin U-Bahn") | 173 / 9 / 146 km (91 mi) | 563,000,000 (2017) | [BVG](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berliner_Verkehrsbetriebe "Berliner Verkehrsbetriebe") / Mainly underground rail system / 24h-service on weekends |
| [Tram](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tram_transport_in_Berlin "Tram transport in Berlin") | 404 / 22 / 194 km (121 mi) | 197,000,000 (2017) | BVG / Operates predominantly in eastern boroughs |
| [Bus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bus_transport_in_Berlin "Bus transport in Berlin") | 3227 / 198 / 1,675 km (1,041 mi) | 440,000,000 (2017) | BVG / Extensive services in all boroughs / 62 Night Lines |
| [Ferry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferry_transport_in_Berlin "Ferry transport in Berlin") | 6 lines |  | BVG / Transportation as well as recreational ferries |

Travelers can access all modes of transport with a single ticket.

Public transport in Berlin has a long and complicated history because of the 20th-century division of the city, where movement between the two halves was not served. Since [1989](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1989 "1989"), the transport network has been developed extensively; however, it still contains early 20th century traits, such as the U1.<sup id="cite_ref-174"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-174">[172]</a></sup>

#### Airports\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=34 "Edit section: Airports")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Berlin_Brandenburg_Airport_at_night.jpg/220px-Berlin_Brandenburg_Airport_at_night.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Berlin_Brandenburg_Airport_at_night.jpg)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Lage_der_Berliner_Flugh%C3%A4fen.svg/220px-Lage_der_Berliner_Flugh%C3%A4fen.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Lage_der_Berliner_Flugh%C3%A4fen.svg)

Airports in Berlin, including those that are no longer used (as of November 2020)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Markierung_der_Choriner_Stra%C3%9Fe_Berlin_Prenzlauer_Berg_als_Fahrradstra%C3%9Fe.jpg/220px-Markierung_der_Choriner_Stra%C3%9Fe_Berlin_Prenzlauer_Berg_als_Fahrradstra%C3%9Fe.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Markierung_der_Choriner_Stra%C3%9Fe_Berlin_Prenzlauer_Berg_als_Fahrradstra%C3%9Fe.jpg)

Berlin is served by one commercial international airport: [Berlin Brandenburg Airport](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_Brandenburg_Airport "Berlin Brandenburg Airport") (BER), located just outside Berlin's south-eastern border, in the state of Brandenburg. It began construction in 2006, with the intention of replacing [Tegel Airport](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_Tegel_Airport "Berlin Tegel Airport") (TXL) and [Schönefeld Airport](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_Sch%C3%B6nefeld_Airport "Berlin Schönefeld Airport") (SXF) as the single commercial airport of Berlin.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_2018-11-06_175-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-BBC_2018-11-06-175">[173]</a></sup> Previously set to open in 2012, after extensive delays and cost overruns, it opened for commercial operations in October 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-176"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-176">[174]</a></sup> The planned initial capacity of around 27 million passengers per year<sup id="cite_ref-177"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-177">[175]</a></sup> is to be further developed to bring the terminal capacity to approximately 55 million per year by 2040.<sup id="cite_ref-178"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-178">[176]</a></sup>

Before the opening of the BER in Brandenburg, Berlin was served by Tegel Airport and Schönefeld Airport. Tegel Airport was within the city limits, and Schönefeld Airport was located at the same site as the BER. Both airports together handled 29.5 million passengers in 2015. In 2014, 67 airlines served 163 destinations in 50 countries from Berlin.<sup id="cite_ref-179"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-179">[177]</a></sup> Tegel Airport was a focus city for [Lufthansa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lufthansa "Lufthansa") and [Eurowings](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eurowings "Eurowings") while Schönefeld served as an important destination for airlines like [Germania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Germania_(airline) "Germania (airline)"), [easyJet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/EasyJet "EasyJet") and [Ryanair](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ryanair "Ryanair"). Until 2008, Berlin was also served by the smaller [Tempelhof Airport](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tempelhof_Airport "Tempelhof Airport"), which functioned as a city airport, with a convenient location near the city center, allowing for quick transit times between the central business district and the airport. The airport grounds have since been turned into a city park.

#### Cycling\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=35 "Edit section: Cycling")\]

Berlin is well known for its highly developed bicycle lane system.<sup id="cite_ref-180"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-180">[178]</a></sup> It is estimated Berlin has 710 bicycles per 1000 residents. Around 500,000 daily bike riders accounted for 13% of total traffic in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-181"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-181">[179]</a></sup> Cyclists have access to 620 km (385 mi) of bicycle paths including approximately 150 km (93 mi) of mandatory bicycle paths, 190 km (118 mi) of off-road bicycle routes, 60 km (37 mi) of bicycle lanes on roads, 70 km (43 mi) of shared bus lanes which are also open to cyclists, 100 km (62 mi) of combined pedestrian/bike paths and 50 km (31 mi) of marked bicycle lanes on roadside pavements (or sidewalks).<sup id="cite_ref-182"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-182">[180]</a></sup> Riders are allowed to carry their bicycles on [Regionalbahn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regionalbahn "Regionalbahn"), S-Bahn and U-Bahn trains, on trams, and on night buses if a bike ticket is purchased.<sup id="cite_ref-183"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-183">[181]</a></sup>

#### Rohrpost (pneumatic postal network)\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=36 "Edit section: Rohrpost (pneumatic postal network)")\]

From 1865 until 1976, Berlin had an extensive [pneumatic postal network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pneumatic_tube "Pneumatic tube"), which at its peak in 1940, totaled 400 kilometers (250 mi) in length. After 1949 the system was split into two separated networks. The West Berlin system in operation and open for public use until 1963, and for government use until 1972. The East Berlin system which inherited the _Hauptelegraphenamt_, the central hub of the system, was in operation until 1976.

### Energy\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=37 "Edit section: Energy")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Berlin-mitte_heizkraftwerk-mitte_20060605_629.jpg/220px-Berlin-mitte_heizkraftwerk-mitte_20060605_629.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Berlin-mitte_heizkraftwerk-mitte_20060605_629.jpg)

Heizkraftwerk Mitte power plant

Berlin's two largest energy provider for private households are the Swedish firm [Vattenfall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vattenfall "Vattenfall") and the Berlin-based company [GASAG](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GASAG "GASAG"). Both offer electric power and natural gas supply. Some of the city's electric energy is imported from nearby power plants in southern [Brandenburg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brandenburg "Brandenburg").<sup id="cite_ref-184"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-184">[182]</a></sup>

As of 2015 the five [largest power plants measured by capacity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_power_stations_in_Germany "List of power stations in Germany") are the Heizkraftwerk Reuter West, the Heizkraftwerk Lichterfelde, the Heizkraftwerk Mitte, the Heizkraftwerk Wilmersdorf, and the Heizkraftwerk Charlottenburg. All of these [power stations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_station "Power station") generate [electricity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electricity_generation "Electricity generation") and [useful heat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heat "Heat") at the same time to facilitate buffering during load peaks.

In 1993 the power grid connections in the Berlin-Brandenburg capital region were renewed. In most of the inner districts of Berlin power lines are underground cables; only a 380 kV and a 110 kV line, which run from Reuter substation to the urban [Autobahn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autobahn "Autobahn"), use overhead lines. The [Berlin 380-kV electric line](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_380-kV_electric_line "Berlin 380-kV electric line") is the backbone of the city's energy grid.

### Health\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=38 "Edit section: Health")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/2016_Charite_Hospital.jpg/220px-2016_Charite_Hospital.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:2016_Charite_Hospital.jpg)

Berlin has a long history of discoveries in medicine and innovations in medical technology.<sup id="cite_ref-185"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-185">[183]</a></sup> The modern history of medicine has been significantly influenced by scientists from Berlin. [Rudolf Virchow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rudolf_Virchow "Rudolf Virchow") was the founder of cellular pathology, while [Robert Koch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Koch "Robert Koch") developed vaccines for anthrax, cholera, and tuberculosis.<sup id="cite_ref-186"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-186">[184]</a></sup>

The [Charité](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charit%C3%A9 "Charité") complex (Universitätsklinik Charité) is the largest [university hospital](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_hospital "University hospital") in Europe, tracing back its origins to the year 1710. More than half of all German Nobel Prize winners in Physiology or Medicine, including [Emil von Behring](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emil_von_Behring "Emil von Behring"), Robert Koch and [Paul Ehrlich](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Ehrlich "Paul Ehrlich"), have worked at the Charité. The Charité is spread over four campuses and comprises around 3,000 beds, 15,500 staff, 8,000 students, and more than 60 operating theaters, and it has a turnover of two billion euros annually.<sup id="cite_ref-charite_facts_187-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-charite_facts-187">[185]</a></sup> The [Charité](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charit%C3%A9 "Charité") is a joint institution of the [Freie Universität Berlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_University_of_Berlin "Free University of Berlin") and the [Humboldt University of Berlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humboldt_University_of_Berlin "Humboldt University of Berlin"), including a wide range of institutes and specialized medical centers.

Among them are the German Heart Center, one of the most renowned transplantation centers, the Max-Delbrück-Center for Molecular Medicine, and the Max-Planck Institute for Molecular Genetics. The scientific research at these institutions is complemented by many research departments of companies such as Siemens and Bayer. The [World Health Summit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Health_Summit "World Health Summit") and several international health-related conventions are held annually in Berlin.

### Telecommunication\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=39 "Edit section: Telecommunication")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/St_oberholz.jpg/220px-St_oberholz.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:St_oberholz.jpg)

Café customers in Berlin Mitte using [Wi-Fi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wi-Fi "Wi-Fi") devices

Since 2017, the [digital television](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_television "Digital television") standard in Berlin and Germany is [DVB-T2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DVB-T2 "DVB-T2"). This system transmits [compressed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_compression "Video compression") [digital audio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_audio "Digital audio"), [digital video](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_video "Digital video") and other data in an [MPEG transport stream](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MPEG_transport_stream "MPEG transport stream").

Berlin has installed several hundred free public [Wireless LAN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wireless_LAN "Wireless LAN") sites across the capital since 2016. The wireless networks are concentrated mostly in central districts; 650 hotspots (325 indoor and 325 outdoor access points) are installed.<sup id="cite_ref-188"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-188">[186]</a></sup> Deutsche Bahn is planning to introduce Wi-Fi services in long-distance and regional trains in 2017.<sup>[<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers"><span title="The date of the event predicted near this tag has passed. (January 2021)">needs update</span></a></i>]</sup>

The [UMTS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UMTS "UMTS") (3G) and [LTE](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LTE_(telecommunication) "LTE (telecommunication)") (4G) networks of the three major cellular operators [Vodafone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vodafone "Vodafone"), [T-Mobile](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T-Mobile "T-Mobile") and [O2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telef%C3%B3nica_Germany "Telefónica Germany") enable the use of mobile broadband applications citywide.

The [Fraunhofer Heinrich Hertz Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fraunhofer_Institute_for_Telecommunications "Fraunhofer Institute for Telecommunications") develops mobile and stationary broadband communication networks and multimedia systems. Focal points are [photonic components and systems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Photonics "Photonics"), [fiber optic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optical_fiber "Optical fiber") sensor systems, and [image signal processing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_image_processing "Digital image processing") and [transmission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signal_processing "Signal processing"). Future applications for broadband networks are developed as well.

## Education and research\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=40 "Edit section: Education and research")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Berlin-Mitte_Humboldt-Uni_05-2014.jpg/220px-Berlin-Mitte_Humboldt-Uni_05-2014.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Berlin-Mitte_Humboldt-Uni_05-2014.jpg)

As of 2014, Berlin had 878 schools, teaching 340,658 students in 13,727 classes and 56,787 trainees in businesses and elsewhere.<sup id="cite_ref-factsheet_140-2"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-factsheet-140">[138]</a></sup> The city has a 6-year primary education program. After completing primary school, students continue to the _Sekundarschule_ (a comprehensive school) or _Gymnasium_ (college preparatory school). Berlin has a special bilingual school program in the _Europaschule_, in which children are taught the curriculum in German and a foreign language, starting in primary school and continuing in high school.<sup id="cite_ref-189"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-189">[187]</a></sup>

The [Französisches Gymnasium Berlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franz%C3%B6sisches_Gymnasium_Berlin "Französisches Gymnasium Berlin"), which was founded in 1689 to teach the children of Huguenot refugees, offers (German/French) instruction.<sup id="cite_ref-190"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-190">[188]</a></sup> The [John F. Kennedy School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_School,_Berlin "John F. Kennedy School, Berlin"), a bilingual German–American public school in [Zehlendorf](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zehlendorf_(Berlin) "Zehlendorf (Berlin)"), is particularly popular with children of diplomats and the English-speaking expatriate community. 82 _Gymnasien_ teach [Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin "Latin")<sup id="cite_ref-191"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-191">[189]</a></sup> and 8 teach [Classical Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_Greek "Classical Greek").<sup id="cite_ref-192"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-192">[190]</a></sup>

### Higher education\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=41 "Edit section: Higher education")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Freie_Universitaet_Berlin_-_Gebaeudekomplex_Rost-_und_Silberlaube.jpg/220px-Freie_Universitaet_Berlin_-_Gebaeudekomplex_Rost-_und_Silberlaube.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Freie_Universitaet_Berlin_-_Gebaeudekomplex_Rost-_und_Silberlaube.jpg)

The [Free University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_University_of_Berlin "Free University of Berlin") is one of Germany's eleven "Universities of Excellence".

The Berlin-Brandenburg capital region is one of the most prolific centers of higher education and research in Germany and Europe. Historically, 67 Nobel Prize winners are affiliated with the Berlin-based universities.

The city has four public research universities and more than 30 private, professional, and technical colleges _(Hochschulen)_, offering a wide range of disciplines.<sup id="cite_ref-193"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-193">[191]</a></sup> A record number of 175,651 students were enrolled in the winter term of 2015/16.<sup id="cite_ref-194"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-194">[192]</a></sup> Among them around 18% have an international background.

The three largest universities combined have approximately 103,000 enrolled students. There are the [Freie Universität Berlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_University_of_Berlin "Free University of Berlin") _(Free University of Berlin, FU Berlin)_ with about 33,000<sup id="cite_ref-195"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-195">[193]</a></sup> students, the [Humboldt Universität zu Berlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humboldt_University_of_Berlin "Humboldt University of Berlin") _(HU Berlin)_ with 35,000<sup id="cite_ref-196"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-196">[194]</a></sup> students, and the [Technische Universität Berlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technical_University_of_Berlin "Technical University of Berlin") _(TU Berlin)_ with 35,000<sup id="cite_ref-197"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-197">[195]</a></sup> students. The [Charité](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charit%C3%A9 "Charité") Medical School has around 8,000 students.<sup id="cite_ref-charite_facts_187-1"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-charite_facts-187">[185]</a></sup> The FU, the HU, the TU, and the Charité make up the [Berlin University Alliance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_University_Alliance "Berlin University Alliance"), which has received funding from the [Excellence Strategy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/German_Universities_Excellence_Initiative "German Universities Excellence Initiative") program of the German government.<sup id="cite_ref-198"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-198">[196]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-199"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-199">[197]</a></sup> The [Universität der Künste](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_University_of_the_Arts "Berlin University of the Arts") _(UdK)_ has about 4,000 students and [ESMT Berlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESMT_Berlin "ESMT Berlin") is only one of four business schools in Germany with [triple accreditation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triple_accreditation "Triple accreditation").<sup id="cite_ref-200"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-200">[198]</a></sup> The [Hertie School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hertie_School "Hertie School"), a private public policy school located in Mitte, has more than 900 students and doctoral students. The [Berlin School of Economics and Law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_School_of_Economics_and_Law "Berlin School of Economics and Law") has an enrollment of about 11,000 students, the [Berlin University of Applied Sciences and Technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berliner_Hochschule_f%C3%BCr_Technik "Berliner Hochschule für Technik") of about 12,000 students, and the [Hochschule für Technik und Wirtschaft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTW_Berlin "HTW Berlin") (University of Applied Sciences for Engineering and Economics) of about 14,000 students.

### Research\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=42 "Edit section: Research")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Berlin_Adlershof_Photonics_Center_2016.jpg/220px-Berlin_Adlershof_Photonics_Center_2016.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Berlin_Adlershof_Photonics_Center_2016.jpg)

The city has a high density of internationally renowned research institutions, such as the [Fraunhofer Society](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fraunhofer_Society "Fraunhofer Society"), the [Leibniz Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leibniz_Association "Leibniz Association"), the [Helmholtz Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helmholtz_Association_of_German_Research_Centres "Helmholtz Association of German Research Centres"), and the [Max Planck Society](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Max_Planck_Society "Max Planck Society"), which are independent of, or only loosely connected to its universities.<sup id="cite_ref-201"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-201">[199]</a></sup> In 2012, around 65,000 professional scientists were working in [research and development](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Research_and_development "Research and development") in the city.<sup id="cite_ref-factsheet_140-3"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-factsheet-140">[138]</a></sup>

Berlin is one of the knowledge and innovation communities (KIC) of the [European Institute of Innovation and Technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Institute_of_Innovation_and_Technology "European Institute of Innovation and Technology") (EIT).<sup id="cite_ref-202"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-202">[200]</a></sup> The KIC is based at the Center for Entrepreneurship at TU Berlin and has a focus in the development of IT industries. It partners with major multinational companies such as [Siemens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siemens "Siemens"), [Deutsche Telekom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deutsche_Telekom "Deutsche Telekom"), and [SAP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SAP_SE "SAP SE").<sup id="cite_ref-203"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-203">[201]</a></sup>

One of Europe's successful research, business and technology [clusters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_technology_centers "List of technology centers") is based at [WISTA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WISTA "WISTA") in [Berlin-Adlershof](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin-Adlershof "Berlin-Adlershof"), with more than 1,000 affiliated firms, university departments and scientific institutions.<sup id="cite_ref-204"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-204">[202]</a></sup>

In addition to the university-affiliated libraries, the [Staatsbibliothek zu Berlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Staatsbibliothek_zu_Berlin "Staatsbibliothek zu Berlin") is a major research library. Its two main locations are on Potsdamer Straße and on [Unter den Linden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unter_den_Linden "Unter den Linden"). There are also 86 public libraries in the city.<sup id="cite_ref-factsheet_140-4"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-factsheet-140">[138]</a></sup> [ResearchGate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ResearchGate "ResearchGate"), a global social networking site for scientists, is based in Berlin.

## Culture\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=43 "Edit section: Culture")\]
