[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Alte_Nationalgalerie_abends_%28Zuschnitt%29.jpg/200px-Alte_Nationalgalerie_abends_%28Zuschnitt%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Alte_Nationalgalerie_abends_(Zuschnitt).jpg)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Cafe_am_Holzmarkt%2C_River_Spree%2C_Berlin_%2846636049685%29.jpg/220px-Cafe_am_Holzmarkt%2C_River_Spree%2C_Berlin_%2846636049685%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Cafe_am_Holzmarkt,_River_Spree,_Berlin_(46636049685).jpg)

Berlin is known for its numerous cultural institutions, many of which enjoy international reputation.<sup id="cite_ref-UNESCO_25-1"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-UNESCO-25">[24]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-UNESCO2_205-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-UNESCO2-205">[203]</a></sup> The diversity and vivacity of the metropolis led to a trendsetting atmosphere.<sup id="cite_ref-206"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-206">[204]</a></sup> An innovative music, dance and art scene has developed in the 21st century.

Young people, international artists and entrepreneurs continued to settle in the city and made Berlin a popular entertainment center in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-207"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-207">[205]</a></sup>

The expanding cultural performance of the city was underscored by the relocation of the [Universal Music Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_Music_Group "Universal Music Group") who decided to move their headquarters to the banks of the River Spree.<sup id="cite_ref-208"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-208">[206]</a></sup> In 2005, Berlin was named "City of Design" by [UNESCO](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO") and has been part of the [Creative Cities Network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Creative_Cities_Network "Creative Cities Network") ever since.<sup id="cite_ref-209"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-209">[207]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Cityofdesign_21-1"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-Cityofdesign-21">[20]</a></sup>

Many German and International films were shot in Berlin, including [M](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/M_(1931_film) "M (1931 film)"), [One, Two, Three](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One,_Two,_Three "One, Two, Three"), [Cabaret](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cabaret_(1972_film) "Cabaret (1972 film)"), [Christiane F.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christiane_F._(film) "Christiane F. (film)"), [Possession](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Possession_(1981_film) "Possession (1981 film)"), [Octopussy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Octopussy "Octopussy"), [Wings of Desire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wings_of_Desire "Wings of Desire"), [Run Lola Run](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Run_Lola_Run "Run Lola Run"), [The Bourne Trilogy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bourne_(film_series) "Bourne (film series)"), [Good Bye, Lenin!](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Good_Bye,_Lenin! "Good Bye, Lenin!"), [The Lives of Others](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Lives_of_Others "The Lives of Others"), [Inglourious Basterds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inglourious_Basterds "Inglourious Basterds"), [Hanna](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hanna_(film) "Hanna (film)"), [Unknown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unknown_(2011_film) "Unknown (2011 film)") and [Bridge of Spies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bridge_of_Spies_(film) "Bridge of Spies (film)").

### Galleries and museums\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=44 "Edit section: Galleries and museums")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/JewishMuseumBerlin.jpg/220px-JewishMuseumBerlin.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:JewishMuseumBerlin.jpg)

As of 2011 Berlin is home to 138 museums and more than 400 art galleries.<sup id="cite_ref-factsheet_140-5"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-factsheet-140">[138]</a></sup> <sup id="cite_ref-210"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-210">[208]</a></sup> The ensemble on the [Museum Island](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_Island "Museum Island") is a UNESCO [World Heritage Site](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site") and is in the northern part of the Spree Island between the Spree and the Kupfergraben.<sup id="cite_ref-UNESCO_25-2"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-UNESCO-25">[24]</a></sup> As early as 1841 it was designated a "district dedicated to art and antiquities" by a royal decree. Subsequently, the [Altes Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altes_Museum "Altes Museum") was built in the Lustgarten. The [Neues Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neues_Museum "Neues Museum"), which displays the [bust of Queen Nefertiti](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nefertiti_Bust "Nefertiti Bust"),<sup id="cite_ref-211"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-211">[209]</a></sup> [Alte Nationalgalerie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alte_Nationalgalerie "Alte Nationalgalerie"), [Pergamon Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pergamon_Museum "Pergamon Museum"), and [Bode Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bode_Museum "Bode Museum") were built there.

Apart from the Museum Island, there are many additional museums in the city. The [Gemäldegalerie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gem%C3%A4ldegalerie,_Berlin "Gemäldegalerie, Berlin") (Painting Gallery) focuses on the paintings of the "old masters" from the 13th to the 18th centuries, while the [Neue Nationalgalerie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neue_Nationalgalerie "Neue Nationalgalerie") (New National Gallery, built by [Ludwig Mies van der Rohe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ludwig_Mies_van_der_Rohe "Ludwig Mies van der Rohe")) specializes in 20th-century European painting. The [Hamburger Bahnhof](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamburger_Bahnhof "Hamburger Bahnhof"), in [Moabit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moabit "Moabit"), exhibits a major collection of modern and contemporary art. The expanded [Deutsches Historisches Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deutsches_Historisches_Museum "Deutsches Historisches Museum") reopened in the Zeughaus with an overview of German history spanning more than a millennium. The [Bauhaus Archive](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bauhaus_Archive "Bauhaus Archive") is a museum of 20th-century design from the famous [Bauhaus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bauhaus "Bauhaus") school. [Museum Berggruen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_Berggruen "Museum Berggruen") houses the collection of noted 20th century collector [Heinz Berggruen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_Berggruen "Heinz Berggruen"), and features an extensive assortment of works by [Picasso](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Picasso "Picasso"), [Matisse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matisse "Matisse"), [Cézanne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C%C3%A9zanne "Cézanne"), and [Giacometti](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giacometti "Giacometti"), among others.<sup id="cite_ref-212"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-212">[210]</a></sup> The [Kupferstichkabinett](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kupferstichkabinett_Berlin "Kupferstichkabinett Berlin") Berlin (Museum of Prints and Drawings) is part of the [Staatlichen Museen zu Berlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_State_Museums "Berlin State Museums") (Berlin State Museums) and the [Kulturforum at Potsdamer Platz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kulturforum "Kulturforum") in the Tiergarten district of Berlin's Mitte district. It is the largest museum of the graphic arts in Germany and at the same time one of the four most important collections of its kind in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-213"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-213">[211]</a></sup> The collection includes [Friedrich Gilly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friedrich_Gilly "Friedrich Gilly")'s design for the monument to Frederick II of Prussia.<sup id="cite_ref-214"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-214">[212]</a></sup>

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Ishtar_Gate_at_Berlin_Museum.jpg/220px-Ishtar_Gate_at_Berlin_Museum.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Ishtar_Gate_at_Berlin_Museum.jpg)

The [Jewish Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jewish_Museum_Berlin "Jewish Museum Berlin") has a standing exhibition on two millennia of German-Jewish history.<sup id="cite_ref-215"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-215">[213]</a></sup> The [German Museum of Technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/German_Museum_of_Technology_(Berlin) "German Museum of Technology (Berlin)") in [Kreuzberg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kreuzberg "Kreuzberg") has a large collection of historical technical artifacts. The _[Museum für Naturkunde](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_History_Museum,_Berlin "Natural History Museum, Berlin")_ (Berlin's [natural history museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_history_museum "Natural history museum")) exhibits [natural history](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_history "Natural history") near [Berlin Hauptbahnhof](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_Hauptbahnhof "Berlin Hauptbahnhof"). It has the largest mounted dinosaur in the world (a _[Giraffatitan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giraffatitan "Giraffatitan")_ skeleton). A well-preserved specimen of _[Tyrannosaurus rex](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tyrannosaurus "Tyrannosaurus")_ and the early bird _[Archaeopteryx](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Archaeopteryx "Archaeopteryx")_ are at display as well.<sup id="cite_ref-216"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-216">[214]</a></sup>

In [Dahlem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dahlem_(Berlin) "Dahlem (Berlin)"), there are several museums of world art and culture, such as the [Museum of Asian Art](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Asian_Art "Museum of Asian Art"), the [Ethnological Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethnological_Museum_of_Berlin "Ethnological Museum of Berlin"), the [Museum of European Cultures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_Europ%C3%A4ischer_Kulturen "Museum Europäischer Kulturen"), as well as the [Allied Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allied_Museum "Allied Museum"). The [Brücke Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Br%C3%BCcke_Museum "Brücke Museum") features one of the largest collection of works by artist of the early 20th-century expressionist movement. In [Lichtenberg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lichtenberg "Lichtenberg"), on the grounds of the former [East German Ministry for State Security](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stasi "Stasi"), is the [Stasi Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stasi_Museum "Stasi Museum"). The site of [Checkpoint Charlie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Checkpoint_Charlie "Checkpoint Charlie"), one of the most renowned crossing points of the Berlin Wall, is still preserved. A private [museum venture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Checkpoint_Charlie_Museum "Checkpoint Charlie Museum") exhibits a comprehensive documentation of detailed plans and strategies devised by people who tried to flee from the East.

The [Beate Uhse Erotic Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beate_Uhse_Erotic_Museum "Beate Uhse Erotic Museum") claimed to be the largest erotic museum in the world until it closed in 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-217"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-217">[215]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-218"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-218">[216]</a></sup>

The cityscape of Berlin displays large quantities of urban [street art](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Street_art "Street art").<sup id="cite_ref-219"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-219">[217]</a></sup> It has become a significant part of the city's cultural heritage and has its roots in the graffiti scene of [Kreuzberg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kreuzberg "Kreuzberg") of the 1980s.<sup id="cite_ref-220"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-220">[218]</a></sup> The [Berlin Wall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_Wall_graffiti_art "Berlin Wall graffiti art") itself has become one of the largest open-air canvasses in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-221"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-221">[219]</a></sup> The leftover stretch along the Spree river in [Friedrichshain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friedrichshain "Friedrichshain") remains as the [East Side Gallery](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Side_Gallery "East Side Gallery"). Berlin today is consistently rated as an important world city for street art culture.<sup id="cite_ref-222"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-222">[220]</a></sup> Berlin has galleries which are quite rich in contemporary art. Located in Mitte, KW Institute for Contemporary Art, KOW, Sprüth Magers; Kreuzberg there are a few galleries as well such as Blain Southern, [Esther Schipper](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Esther_Schipper "Esther Schipper"), Future Gallery, König Gallerie.

### Nightlife and festivals\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=45 "Edit section: Nightlife and festivals")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/20150208_-_Berlinale_Palast_and_Red_Carpet.JPG/220px-20150208_-_Berlinale_Palast_and_Red_Carpet.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:20150208_-_Berlinale_Palast_and_Red_Carpet.JPG)

The [Berlinale](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlinale "Berlinale") is the largest international spectator film festival.

Berlin's nightlife has been celebrated as one of the most diverse and vibrant of its kind.<sup id="cite_ref-223"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-223">[221]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-224"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-224">[222]</a></sup> In the 1970s and 80s, the [SO36](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SO36 "SO36") in [Kreuzberg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kreuzberg "Kreuzberg") was a center for [punk music](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punk_music "Punk music") and culture. The _SOUND_ and the _Dschungel_ gained notoriety. Throughout the 1990s, people in their 20s from all over the world, particularly those in [Western](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Europe "Western Europe") and Central Europe, made Berlin's club scene a premier nightlife venue. After the [fall of the Berlin Wall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fall_of_the_Berlin_Wall "Fall of the Berlin Wall") in 1989, many historic buildings in Mitte, the former city center of East Berlin, were illegally occupied and re-built by young squatters and became a fertile ground for underground and [counterculture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Counterculture "Counterculture") gatherings.<sup id="cite_ref-225"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-225">[223]</a></sup> The central boroughs are home to many nightclubs, including the Watergate, [Tresor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tresor_(club) "Tresor (club)") and [Berghain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berghain "Berghain"). The [KitKatClub](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KitKatClub "KitKatClub") and several other locations are known for their sexually uninhibited parties.

Clubs are not required to close at a fixed time during the weekends, and many parties last well into the morning or even all weekend. The _Weekend Club_ near [Alexanderplatz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexanderplatz "Alexanderplatz") features a roof terrace that allows partying at night. Several venues have become a popular stage for the [Neo-Burlesque](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neo-Burlesque "Neo-Burlesque") scene.

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Festival_of_Lights_2012_-_Franz%C3%B6sischer_Dom.jpg/220px-Festival_of_Lights_2012_-_Franz%C3%B6sischer_Dom.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Festival_of_Lights_2012_-_Franz%C3%B6sischer_Dom.jpg)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Hanukkah%2C_Brandenburg_Gate_%28Berlin%29.jpg/220px-Hanukkah%2C_Brandenburg_Gate_%28Berlin%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Hanukkah,_Brandenburg_Gate_(Berlin).jpg)

[Hanukkah](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hanukkah "Hanukkah") festival at the Brandenburg Gate

Berlin has a long history of gay culture, and is an important [birthplace of the LGBT rights movement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientific-Humanitarian_Committee "Scientific-Humanitarian Committee"). Same-sex bars and dance halls operated freely as early as the 1880s, and the first gay magazine, _Der Eigene_, started in 1896. By the 1920s, gays and lesbians had an unprecedented visibility.<sup id="cite_ref-Krauss_226-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-Krauss-226">[224]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-The_New_Yorker_227-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-The_New_Yorker-227">[225]</a></sup> Today, in addition to a positive atmosphere in the wider club scene, the city again has a huge number of queer clubs and festivals. The most famous and largest are [Berlin Pride](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_Pride "Berlin Pride"), the [Christopher Street Day](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_Street_Day "Christopher Street Day"),<sup id="cite_ref-228"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-228">[226]</a></sup> the [Lesbian and Gay City Festival](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lesbian_and_Gay_City_Festival "Lesbian and Gay City Festival") in Berlin-Schöneberg, the [Kreuzberg Pride](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kreuzberg_Pride "Kreuzberg Pride") and [Hustlaball](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hustlaball "Hustlaball").

The annual [Berlin International Film Festival](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_International_Film_Festival "Berlin International Film Festival") (Berlinale) with around 500,000 admissions is considered to be the largest publicly attended film festival in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-229"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-229">[227]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-230"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-230">[228]</a></sup> The Karneval der Kulturen (_Carnival of Cultures_), a multi-ethnic street parade, is celebrated every [Pentecost](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pentecost "Pentecost") weekend.<sup id="cite_ref-231"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-231">[229]</a></sup> Berlin is also well known for the cultural festival [Berliner Festspiele](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berliner_Festspiele "Berliner Festspiele"), which includes the jazz festival [JazzFest Berlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JazzFest_Berlin "JazzFest Berlin"), and [Young Euro Classic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Young_Euro_Classic "Young Euro Classic"), the largest international festival of [youth orchestras](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Youth_orchestra "Youth orchestra") in the world. Several technology and media art festivals and conferences are held in the city, including [Transmediale](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transmediale "Transmediale") and [Chaos Communication Congress](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chaos_Communication_Congress "Chaos Communication Congress"). The annual [Berlin Festival](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_Festival "Berlin Festival") focuses on indie rock, electronic music and synthpop and is part of the International Berlin Music Week.<sup id="cite_ref-232"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-232">[230]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-233"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-233">[231]</a></sup> Every year Berlin hosts one of the largest New Year's Eve celebrations in the world, attended by well over a million people. The focal point is the Brandenburg Gate, where midnight fireworks are centered, but various private fireworks displays take place throughout the entire city. Partygoers in Germany often toast the New Year with a glass of [sparkling wine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sekt "Sekt").

### Performing arts\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=46 "Edit section: Performing arts")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Rattle_BPH-Rittershaus1-Wikipedia.jpg/220px-Rattle_BPH-Rittershaus1-Wikipedia.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Rattle_BPH-Rittershaus1-Wikipedia.jpg)

Berlin is home to 44 theaters and stages.<sup id="cite_ref-factsheet_140-6"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-factsheet-140">[138]</a></sup> The [Deutsches Theater](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deutsches_Theater_(Berlin) "Deutsches Theater (Berlin)") in Mitte was built in 1849–50 and has operated almost continuously since then. The [Volksbühne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volksb%C3%BChne "Volksbühne") at [Rosa-Luxemburg-Platz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rosa-Luxemburg-Platz "Rosa-Luxemburg-Platz") was built in 1913–14, though the company had been founded in 1890. The [Berliner Ensemble](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berliner_Ensemble "Berliner Ensemble"), famous for performing the works of [Bertolt Brecht](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bertolt_Brecht "Bertolt Brecht"), was established in 1949. The [Schaubühne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schaub%C3%BChne "Schaubühne") was founded in 1962 and moved to the building of the former Universum Cinema on Kurfürstendamm in 1981. With a [seating capacity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seating_capacity "Seating capacity") of 1,895 and a stage floor of 2,854 square meters (30,720 sq ft), the [Friedrichstadt-Palast](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friedrichstadt-Palast "Friedrichstadt-Palast") in Berlin Mitte is the largest show palace in Europe.

Berlin has three major [opera houses](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opera_house "Opera house"): the [Deutsche Oper](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deutsche_Oper "Deutsche Oper"), the [Berlin State Opera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_State_Opera "Berlin State Opera"), and the [Komische Oper](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Komische_Oper "Komische Oper"). The Berlin State Opera on [Unter den Linden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unter_den_Linden "Unter den Linden") opened in 1742 and is the oldest of the three. Its musical director is [Daniel Barenboim](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_Barenboim "Daniel Barenboim"). The Komische Oper has traditionally specialized in [operettas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operetta "Operetta") and is also at Unter den Linden. The Deutsche Oper opened in 1912 in Charlottenburg.

The city's main venue for musical theater performances are the Theater am Potsdamer Platz and [Theater des Westens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theater_des_Westens "Theater des Westens") (built in 1895). Contemporary dance can be seen at the _Radialsystem V_. The [Tempodrom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tempodrom "Tempodrom") is host to concerts and circus-inspired entertainment. It also houses a multi-sensory spa experience. The [Admiralspalast](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Admiralspalast "Admiralspalast") in Mitte has a vibrant program of variety and music events.

There are seven symphony orchestras in Berlin. The [Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_Philharmonic_Orchestra "Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra") is one of the preeminent orchestras in the world;<sup id="cite_ref-234"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-234">[232]</a></sup> it is housed in the [Berliner Philharmonie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berliner_Philharmonie "Berliner Philharmonie") near Potsdamer Platz on a street named for the orchestra's longest-serving conductor, [Herbert von Karajan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herbert_von_Karajan "Herbert von Karajan").<sup id="cite_ref-235"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-235">[233]</a></sup> [Simon Rattle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simon_Rattle "Simon Rattle") was its principal conductor from 1999 to 2018, a position now held by [Kirill Petrenko](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kirill_Petrenko "Kirill Petrenko"). The [Konzerthausorchester Berlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Konzerthausorchester_Berlin "Konzerthausorchester Berlin") was founded in 1952 as the orchestra for East Berlin. [Ivan Fischer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ivan_Fischer "Ivan Fischer") is its principal conductor. The [Haus der Kulturen der Welt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haus_der_Kulturen_der_Welt "Haus der Kulturen der Welt") presents exhibitions dealing with intercultural issues and stages world music and conferences.<sup id="cite_ref-236"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-236">[234]</a></sup> The _Kookaburra_ and the _Quatsch Comedy Club_ are known for satire and comedy shows. In 2018, the _[New York Times](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")_ described Berlin as "arguably the world capital of underground [electronic music](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electronic_music "Electronic music")".<sup id="cite_ref-237"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-237">[235]</a></sup>

### Cuisine\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=47 "Edit section: Cuisine")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Berlin-Mitte_Deutsches_Currywurst_Museum.jpg/200px-Berlin-Mitte_Deutsches_Currywurst_Museum.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Berlin-Mitte_Deutsches_Currywurst_Museum.jpg)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Currywurst-1.jpg/192px-Currywurst-1.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Currywurst-1.jpg)

Invented in Berlin, currywurst is an icon of German popular culture and cuisine.

The [cuisine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/German_cuisine "German cuisine") and culinary offerings of Berlin vary greatly. 23 restaurants in Berlin have been awarded one or more [Michelin stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michelin_Guide#Stars "Michelin Guide") in the [Michelin Guide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michelin_Guide "Michelin Guide") of 2021, which ranks the city at the top for the number of restaurants having this distinction in Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-MichelinGuide-2021_238-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-MichelinGuide-2021-238">[236]</a></sup> Berlin is well known for its offerings of vegetarian<sup id="cite_ref-239"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-239">[237]</a></sup> and [vegan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Veganism "Veganism")<sup id="cite_ref-240"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-240">[238]</a></sup> cuisine and is home to an innovative entrepreneurial food scene promoting cosmopolitan flavors, local and sustainable ingredients, pop-up street food markets, supper clubs, as well as food festivals, such as Berlin Food Week.<sup id="cite_ref-241"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-241">[239]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-242"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-242">[240]</a></sup>

Many local foods originated from north German culinary traditions and include rustic and hearty dishes with pork, goose, fish, peas, beans, cucumbers, or potatoes. Typical Berliner fare include popular [street food](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Street_food "Street food") like the _[Currywurst](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Currywurst "Currywurst")_ (which gained popularity with postwar construction workers rebuilding the city), _[Buletten](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frikadeller "Frikadeller")_ and the _[Berliner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berliner_(doughnut) "Berliner (doughnut)")_ donut, known in Berlin as _Pfannkuchen_.<sup id="cite_ref-243"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-243">[241]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-244"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-244">[242]</a></sup> German bakeries offering a variety of breads and pastries are widespread. One of Europe's largest [delicatessen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delicatessen "Delicatessen") markets is found at the [KaDeWe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KaDeWe "KaDeWe"), and among the world's largest chocolate stores is _Fassbender & Rausch_.<sup id="cite_ref-245"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-245">[243]</a></sup>

Berlin is also home to a diverse gastronomy scene reflecting the immigrant history of the city. Turkish and Arab immigrants brought their culinary traditions to the city, such as the [lahmajoun](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lahmajoun "Lahmajoun") and [falafel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Falafel "Falafel"), which have become common fast food staples. The modern fast-food version of the [doner kebab](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doner_kebab "Doner kebab") sandwich which [evolved in Berlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kadir_Nurman "Kadir Nurman") in the 1970s, has since become a favorite dish in Germany and elsewhere in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-WSJ_246-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-WSJ-246">[244]</a></sup> Asian cuisine like Chinese, Vietnamese, Thai, Indian, Korean, and Japanese restaurants, as well as Spanish tapas bars, Italian, and Greek cuisine, can be found in many parts of the city.

### Recreation\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=48 "Edit section: Recreation")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Berlin_Elefantentor_09-2017.jpg/220px-Berlin_Elefantentor_09-2017.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Berlin_Elefantentor_09-2017.jpg)

[Zoologischer Garten Berlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_Zoological_Garden "Berlin Zoological Garden"), the older of two zoos in the city, was founded in 1844. It is the most visited zoo in Europe and presents the most diverse range of species in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-247"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-247">[245]</a></sup> It was the home of the captive-born celebrity polar bear [Knut](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knut_(polar_bear) "Knut (polar bear)").<sup id="cite_ref-knutbbc1_248-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-knutbbc1-248">[246]</a></sup> The city's other zoo, [Tierpark Friedrichsfelde](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tierpark_Berlin "Tierpark Berlin"), was founded in 1955.

[Berlin's Botanischer Garten](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin-Dahlem_Botanical_Garden_and_Botanical_Museum "Berlin-Dahlem Botanical Garden and Botanical Museum") includes the Botanic Museum Berlin. With an area of 43 hectares (110 acres) and around 22,000 different plant species, it is one of the largest and most diverse collections of botanical life in the world. Other gardens in the city include the [Britzer Garten](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Britzer_Garten "Britzer Garten"), and the [Gärten der Welt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erholungspark_Marzahn "Erholungspark Marzahn") (Gardens of the World) in Marzahn.<sup id="cite_ref-249"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-249">[247]</a></sup>

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Siegess%C3%A4ule10.jpg/220px-Siegess%C3%A4ule10.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Siegess%C3%A4ule10.jpg)

The [Tiergarten park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tiergarten_(park) "Tiergarten (park)") in Mitte, with landscape design by [Peter Joseph Lenné](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Joseph_Lenn%C3%A9 "Peter Joseph Lenné"), is one of Berlin's largest and most popular parks.<sup id="cite_ref-250"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-250">[248]</a></sup> In Kreuzberg, the [Viktoriapark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viktoriapark "Viktoriapark") provides a viewing point over the southern part of inner-city Berlin. [Treptower Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Treptower_Park "Treptower Park"), beside the Spree in [Treptow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Treptow "Treptow"), features a large [Soviet War Memorial](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_War_Memorial_(Treptower_Park) "Soviet War Memorial (Treptower Park)"). The Volkspark in [Friedrichshain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friedrichshain "Friedrichshain"), which opened in 1848, is the oldest park in the city, with monuments, a summer outdoor cinema and several sports areas.<sup id="cite_ref-251"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-251">[249]</a></sup> [Tempelhofer Feld](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tempelhofer_Feld "Tempelhofer Feld"), the site of the former [city airport](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_Tempelhof_Airport "Berlin Tempelhof Airport"), is the world's largest inner-city open space.<sup id="cite_ref-252"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-252">[250]</a></sup>

[Potsdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Potsdam "Potsdam") is on the southwestern periphery of Berlin. The city was a residence of the [Prussian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prussia "Prussia") kings and the [German Kaiser](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/German_Emperor "German Emperor"), until 1918. The area around Potsdam in particular [Sanssouci](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sanssouci "Sanssouci") is known for a series of interconnected lakes and cultural landmarks. The [Palaces and Parks of Potsdam and Berlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palaces_and_Parks_of_Potsdam_and_Berlin "Palaces and Parks of Potsdam and Berlin") are the largest [World Heritage Site](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site") in Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-253"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-253">[251]</a></sup>

Berlin is also well known for its numerous cafés, street musicians, beach bars along the Spree River, flea markets, boutique shops and [pop-up stores](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pop-up_store "Pop-up store"), which are a source for recreation and leisure.<sup id="cite_ref-254"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-254">[252]</a></sup>

## Sports\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=49 "Edit section: Sports")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Berliner_Olympiastadion_night_2.jpg/220px-Berliner_Olympiastadion_night_2.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Berliner_Olympiastadion_night_2.jpg)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Berlin_marathon.jpg/220px-Berlin_marathon.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Berlin_marathon.jpg)

Berlin has established a high-profile as a host city of major international sporting events.<sup id="cite_ref-255"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-255">[253]</a></sup> The city hosted the [1936 Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1936_Summer_Olympics "1936 Summer Olympics") and was the host city for the [2006 FIFA World Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup "2006 FIFA World Cup") final.<sup id="cite_ref-256"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-256">[254]</a></sup> The [IAAF World Championships in Athletics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IAAF_World_Championships_in_Athletics "IAAF World Championships in Athletics") was held in the [Olympiastadion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olympiastadion_(Berlin) "Olympiastadion (Berlin)") in 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-257"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-257">[255]</a></sup> The city hosted the Basketball [Euroleague Final Four](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euroleague_Final_Four "Euroleague Final Four") in [2009](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Euroleague_Final_Four "2009 Euroleague Final Four") and [2016](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Euroleague_Final_Four "2016 Euroleague Final Four").<sup id="cite_ref-258"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-258">[256]</a></sup> and was one of the hosts of the FIBA [EuroBasket 2015](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/EuroBasket_2015 "EuroBasket 2015"). In 2015 Berlin became the venue for the [UEFA Champions League Final](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2015 UEFA Champions League Final").

Berlin will host the 2023 Special Olympics World Summer Games. This will be the first time Germany has ever hosted the Special Olympics World Games.<sup id="cite_ref-259"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-259">[257]</a></sup>

The annual [Berlin Marathon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin_Marathon "Berlin Marathon") – a course that holds the most top-10 world record runs – and the [ISTAF](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internationales_Stadionfest "Internationales Stadionfest") are well-established athletic events in the city.<sup id="cite_ref-260"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-260">[258]</a></sup> The [Mellowpark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mellowpark "Mellowpark") in Köpenick is one of the biggest skate and BMX parks in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-261"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-261">[259]</a></sup> A Fan Fest at Brandenburg Gate, which attracts several hundred-thousand spectators, has become popular during international football competitions, like the [UEFA European Championship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UEFA_European_Championship "UEFA European Championship").<sup id="cite_ref-262"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-262">[260]</a></sup>

In 2013 around 600,000 Berliners were registered in one of the more than 2,300 sport and fitness clubs.<sup id="cite_ref-263"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-263">[261]</a></sup> The city of Berlin operates more than 60 public indoor and outdoor swimming pools.<sup id="cite_ref-264"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-264">[262]</a></sup> Berlin is the largest Olympic training center in Germany. About 500 top athletes (15% of all German top athletes) are based there. Forty-seven elite athletes participated in the 2012 Summer Olympics. Berliners would achieve seven gold, twelve silver and three bronze medals.<sup id="cite_ref-265"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-265">[263]</a></sup>

Several professional clubs representing the most important spectator team sports in Germany have their base in Berlin. The oldest and most popular first division team based in Berlin is the football club [Hertha BSC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hertha_BSC "Hertha BSC").<sup id="cite_ref-Hertha_BSC_266-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-Hertha_BSC-266">[264]</a></sup> The team represented Berlin as a founding member of the [Bundesliga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bundesliga "Bundesliga") in 1963. Other professional team sport clubs include:

## Notes\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Berlin&action=edit&section=51 "Edit section: Notes")\]

1.  **[^](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_ref-5 "Jump up")** Prefixes for vehicle registration were introduced in 1906, but often changed due to the political changes after 1945. Vehicles were registered under the following prefixes: "I A" (1906 – April 1945; devalidated on 11 August 1945); no prefix, only digits (from July to August 1945), "БГ" (=BG; 1945–46, for cars, trucks and busses), "ГФ" (=GF; 1945–46, for cars, trucks and busses), "БM" (=BM; 1945–47, for motor bikes), "ГM" (=GM; 1945–47, for motor bikes), "KB" (i.e.: [Kommandatura](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allied_Kommandatura "Allied Kommandatura") of Berlin; for all of Berlin 1947–48, continued for [West Berlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Berlin "West Berlin") until 1956), "GB" (i.e.: Greater Berlin, for [East Berlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Berlin "East Berlin") 1948–53), "I" (for East Berlin, 1953–90), "B" (for West Berlin from 1 July 1956, continued for all of Berlin since 1990).
2.  **[^](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_ref-92 "Jump up")** Because the location of the [weather station](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weather_station "Weather station") is furthest from the more densely urbanized region of Berlin and further away from the main [UHI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urban_heat_island "Urban heat island"), its values will be somewhat higher, especially in the center and immediate regions.<sup id="cite_ref-91"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin#cite_note-91">[90]</a></sup>
